segments.text: They're talking to James Salter.
Let me just put this over here.
I read in your PW interview, you mentioned that you kept a journal while you were in Korea.
Yes.
But this book is recollection.
Yeah, but it doesn't mean you can't have a pony.
I mean, it's certainly not done entirely from memory because it would be quite inaccurate.
if it were.
But I thought that maybe you wanted to rely on memory.
No.
Well.
Because sometimes the things that you remember are probably the most important.
That's true.
And I did rely on memory, that is to say, to identify the things, but to render them accurately.
I used everything I could.
Letters, journal, newspapers, talking to people, whatever.
But it was the selection of things that was memory.
Do you know what I mean?
I know exactly what you mean.
I never kept notes when I was in the service, for instance, and I regret it tremendously.
That's too bad.
I've got a pretty good memory, but I've often thought, if I came to write a book about, it's a very interesting time, I would call that book, Tonkin Gulf Yacht Club, which is the patch we all wore.
It's a great title for an aircraft carrier store.
You know, I didn't keep it dry.
Well, a lot goes away from you if you don't.
And you lose a lot of very, very... Well, you lose the detail.
Yeah.
I mean, you remember certain key things, of course.
May I have some hot water in there?
Nothing more.
Just scalding water.
Thank you.
You said that your years...
in the military as a pilot were the defining years.
I don't know if that's the exact phrase that you've used.
Maybe it's the, not the defining years, but the voyage of your life.
Yes.
Well, that's a bit different.
That is a bit different.
Yeah.
Well, defining years, I would say... That was my paraphrase, which was one.
Okay.
Well, I mean, defining years, I would say, would be school years, essentially.
But after school...
you go out on the voyage, and that happened to be mine.
So who knows what defines you?
I mean, no, you're defined early, I believe, but you make refinement.
You know, there can be adjustments in it as you go along.
But the voyage of your life, could you expand a little bit on that by what you mean?
Well... Beyond the metaphor?
Not really without crushing the metaphor, but...
The voyage of my life actually refers to that tour, to the combat tour in Korea, more than to the whole business of flying.
So I volunteered to go, but I was a regular officer, and we were eager to go as pilots.
You know, it was essential in a way.
And I volunteered to go, and who knew what would happen?
So all those things happened to me that are in that particular chapter.
It's called The Singledarian Act.
The chapter title comes from Melville, as a matter of fact, from Taipei, where he talks about something or other.
The Singledarian Act had put him on the other side.
I don't remember the exact quotation.
I mean, I have it in my notebook, but not in my memory.
And the Singledarian Act refers to an act of Kastler, a guy who was in my flight, who became an ace, wonderful pilot, famous, as a matter of fact.
He won three Air Force crosses, which is the equivalent of, it's above the DSC.
No, it's the equivalent of the DSC, I believe.
That's to say the highest declaration below the Congressional Medal, and I believe the only individual ever to have done that, Kastler.
In any case...
The tour, the combat tour, was all I might have imagined and more.
And to have done it and then left, that's what I referred to as.
I had said it had been a great voyage, the voyage probably of my life.
I agree.
Actually, I think these things that happened, and also it's the event of regeneration probably.
Um, well, no.
It wasn't like the Vietnam War.
Well, I don't recall it that well.
But you see, you didn't participate in the Vietnam War.
That was after your watch.
After my watch.
But the thing is that the Korean War was overshadowed by the Second World War, which had just ended with all its tremendous, you know,
drama of every kind, and then came this remote and unpopular and, to some people, somewhat pointless war.
That was quite different, because then, after a long period, then more than ten years later,
in a period of peace.
Well, the Cold War was on, but that's not really a war.
In a period of peace came Vietnam.
I think it stood out more, and it was much longer.
Didn't Vietnam go on for about eight years, nine or ten years?
And the domestic aspect of the war was completely different than the Korean War.
I mean, it was a watershed.
in American society, and the Korean War was really not.
It was merely, you know, I don't want to say a two-for-a-penny war, because as many people were killed in Korea, almost, the casualty figures are about the same, but it wasn't.
In terms of the domestic consequences and the world consequences, but when I meant the event,
The event of your generation in which you could participate, I guess, is what I think.
Well, I was old enough to have fought in the Second War, but I didn't.
I was commissioned just as it was over.
That was really, I would say, the event, truly the event of my generation.
I didn't write about it because I wasn't in it, but I still think in terms of it.
Really?
Yes, it's inevitable.
You simply, you know, the big events of your life,
You cannot exchange for anything else at the world events.
You just can't switch and say, well, now I'm going to start thinking that it was the Kennedy assassination that was the big event of my life.
But it wasn't, because it came much later.
For me, it was totally the 60s.
I graduated high school in 61, college in 65, went to graduate school in
service from 68 to 71, 68, 68.
Everything happened to me in the 1960s.
But I believe, wouldn't it be true that that is your essential reference in life?
Absolutely.
Well, that's what I'm saying.
The Second World War, even though I didn't fight in it, was really mine.
So to use that word defining again, that almost was a defining event.
Very defining, yes.
It came during school.
School was defined in that war all at the same time.
You mentioned, and you give great credit to Joe Fox for eliciting this book out of you, but did he encourage you as to the shape that you take as recollections as opposed to a memoir?
No.
I was one of Fox's two favorites that he still had.
I mean, he had had lots of writers of importance.
I mean, he edited Capote, Philip Roth, many, you know, in the first rank.
But by the time, in the last 20 years of his life, he had a lot of successful books, of course, but among literary writers,
I was one of the two that he liked.
And the other?
Well, the other that he was tremendously fond of and thought she'd get a Nobel Prize, as a matter of fact, was Mavis Galant, the Canadian writer who lives in Paris.
Of course, she wrote a lot for him.
I wrote very little for him.
He only edited one book of mine, Turn Down Two.
You're killing him.
No.
And...
And then Wanda encouraged me to write the third.
But when it came to the third, no, he didn't say, I think you should do this or that.
He said, you write it.
No, I have confidence in it.
Well, he didn't say I have confidence in it.
He just said that.
That didn't seem to be his way to have confidence in it.
Martin Cruz Smith was, of course, his author, too.
Well, I didn't call him a literary.
I mean, he is.
I suppose he is, really.
He's sort of on that book alone.
He's not a literary.
But he writes a very high-level, well, you know what I mean.
I know precisely what you mean.
By literary author, I mean a respected writer who doesn't sell any books.
Yeah, well...
That's funny.
You did say to some... Cruise sells a lot, yes.
You did say to someone that you're tired of being called a writer's writer.
Well, I don't know why.
I mean, that's... But everybody certainly has the greatest respect for you.
Well, but I mean, the critics and people who interviews her and so forth go back to the file, so to speak, and they say, ah, writer's writer.
Well...
and they pick it up.
I think that's the way it happens.
Did you know Richard Yates, who lived around here in Boston?
No.
Did you know his work at all?
A bit.
Yeah.
He had Revolutionary Road.
Revolutionary Road, 11 Kinds of Loneliness.
I remember talking with Dick Yates right over at the Crossroads, a bar that he liked over there.
over there, actually, that's Boston over there.
And he said, if I knew how to write, believe me, if I knew how to write a bestseller, I would do it tonight.
Of course.
And, you know, he said, but I can only write the way I know how to write.
Do you subscribe to that?
Oh, sure.
I mean, I think that's self-evident.
You know, I think it was Jules Renard who said, if I'm going to translate the French, roughly, he said, you can...
tell stories as you like, anecdotes, stories.
You can entertain as you like, but you cannot write as you like.
You can only write what you are.
That's great.
And I think that's essentially true.
And the rest of this, once again, is it?
Jules Renard, R-E-N-A-R-D.
Go ahead.
I interrupted you.
You were going to say something.
I'm sorry.
I think he said, on peut compter comme on veut, or something like that.
On peut pas écrire comme on veut, on peut écrire ce que on est, or what you are.
My French is probably lousy.
I'm going to have a ball transcribing that one.
Well, no, no.
Don't, because the French is all wrong, I'm sure.
Well, yeah, but I mean, you hear this story all the time.
In fact...
I'm sure this happens to every writer because I can remember having dinner with Fox saying, Christ, I could write a book like that.
I said, he said, you couldn't possibly.
He said, you have to believe in that to be able to write it when you don't.
And I think that's true.
I agree with that, actually.
For the longest time, you resisted.
allowing the first two books to be reissued.
I guess in the first book, finally, you're... Could you tell me why that is, and then what prompted you to change your... Well, I didn't think it was worthy of being reissued, it seemed to me.
I wouldn't call it an insult to the public, but there are plenty of books out there, and it was the first book, useful in many ways.
And although I thought the story was good, I didn't think the writing was measured up to what... I didn't really learn to write to my third book.
And this was the first one.
But the former editor-in-chief of North Point, Jack Shoemaker, a man I have a tremendous amount of respect for, kept after me and said, no, you're being too hard on yourself.
That's not true.
It is an awfully good book.
I know it is.
And I finally agreed to...
having published it, he would let me revise it to take out some of the worst.
So you did go, so this was, you're anticipating my question here.
Go ahead.
This is very interesting.
Well, to take out the inadvertencies or what I thought were, you know, baby fat, let us say.
And so I did the best I could, and he reissued it.
I have been astonished.
at what happened.
You know, first of all, it's the republication of a book.
It's not a new book, of course.
But you tinkered with it, though?
I tinkered with it.
He got a lot of reviews.
It got front-page reviews in certain places.
It's in its third printing now.
Does this astonish you?
Yes, of course, and it's probably going to go into a fourth or fifth.
Isn't that great?
That's wonderful.
Yes, of course it's wonderful, but it makes me feel a bit foolish because I said never in a hundred years, but I was quite wrong.
Do you think maybe you're too self-critical about your work?
Yes, I am, but there I didn't think I was wrong, but I guess I was.
You know what Mencken said, gentlemen, I was mistaken.
But Galileo was the one who said, look, I'll say I'm sorry, but...
but the planets still go around the sun.
You know, sometimes it's self-evident.
So clearly, I've interviewed authors before, and it's an interesting concept to me.
Do you consider completed work completed work as work?
You know, it was your first novel.
You've even gone so far as to suggest it was Juvenalia.
and maybe it should be taken in that context.
What prompts you at this point in your life to want to go back and tinker with something that you wrote 40-odd years ago?
Well, I say I was persuaded by an editor.
But to tinker with it.
Well, I didn't want to let it go as it had been.
Certain things I knew were wrong with it, and I changed them.
He wanted me to write a preface for it to explain.
Not to explain, but to...
helped the reader a bit.
And I did.
And I thought, he wasn't the only one.
The book had, I don't want to say a cult following, because even the word cult makes it sound too numerous.
But I have had letters over the years, letters over the years saying, would you mind if I Xerox several copies of it, because people and so forth.
And then in France, I had a call from, there's a French writer, perhaps you've heard of him, named...
Pierre Klosterman.
He wrote a book right after, bestseller, quite an educated man and a good writer.
He was a fighter pilot in the Second War, and he wrote a book called The Big Circus.
I know that.
I know that.
Well, it was a big, it was a huge success.
Klosterman went on to write seven or eight other books.
He became a deputy to the assembly.
He's a head of, I don't know, international fishing.
I don't know.
He's a man of many, you know, accomplishments.
He called me.

one day and said uh and he speaks english of course quite well and he said well you know i your book is ever published here i would love to write a forward for it this was before it was reissued in america so you know these things add up and you begin to say i'm not as smart perhaps i'm not as good a judge of these things as i thought so
Tim O'Brien who wrote Going After Cacciato, which is the Vietnam book, and I did interview him in fact writing this building with him, his most recent book.
Again, the Vietnam War is seared, I mean, his experiences.
But he has very quietly gone back and fooled around with Cacciato.
It was a book that won the National Booking Award.
In fact, he said he got a letter from a teacher who was in a course, and he was reading the hardcover.
And the students were reading the paperback, and they were saying, we're not reading the same, you know, we're not reading the same book, because he had made changes very quietly.
And I said, Tim, don't you feel that this book represents where you were, what you were at that point in your life?
And I guess I'm asking you the same question.
Oh, but that's making a monument of that.
He said, my responsibility is to make the best work of art that I can.
He said, that's what I feel.
And, you know, so I guess we're all entitled to different opinions on it.
Yeah, well, I wouldn't call, I wouldn't use the term work of art myself.
But, no, no, I agree with O'Brien.
that if it can be improved, and you have the opportunity.

I mean, it's not like Bonnard, who was known for carrying a little tin of paints in his jacket, and when he went to the home of a collector and happened to see one of his paintings, he was not above going up and making some... Oh, that's wonderful.
No, that's true.
Oh, yeah, quite true.
I might use that.
Well, it's exactly what O'Brien did, and in a sense what I did.
as well, yes.
So, no, why not?
Well, when Henry James was bringing out the New York edition of his works, he was just supposed to be writing prefaces, and he's going in there, and he's fooling around.
Well, I think he wanted to do that.
I mean... That's interesting, you know.
You get a lot of opposite views on that from other novelists, you know.
What would be the...
The completed work is completed work, and why go back to something that you finished?
Why not go ahead and do something new?
This represents who I was at that point in my life and at that stage of my development.
Well, that's a very self-important attitude, really.
Perhaps that's okay in the case of a Leonardo, but in lesser cases, I would say the book is the primary thing and not what it represents historically.
If the book can be made...
a little bit more interesting, I wouldn't hesitate to do that.
I mean, there's a limit, I think, to tinkering.
You finally abandon these things, isn't that right?
I mean, you reach a certain point and you say, that's as much, that's as good as I can make it.
Or as good as I want to make it, one or the other.
Well, okay.
Because sometimes you say, I've had it.
Yes, yes.
Well, you may lose heart in a way.
But it depends how tenacious you are or how important the work is.
I mean, you can't do that with a newspaper column, obviously, but if it's a book, you may stick at it, stay at it longer.
I know with my book I was tinkering, tinkering, tinkering up until the day the thing went off and they ordered me not to call them anymore.
Well, I think that's true.
Because we've had six plittings, I've actually been able to go in and fix things.
And I don't hesitate.
This is a work of non-fiction, not an album.
Well, I am going to make some changes in the paperback edition.
Yes, and I'm making some changes.
Substantive ones?
No.
I mean, well, they're substantive to me.

Probably unnoticeable to the average reader, but things that I think... Well, stylistic in the writing, or things that you're going to add in terms of... No, I'm going to add a little bit and change just a word or two.
Everything counts.
you know, even in a long book.
Do you give readings?
Oh, yeah.
Have you ever attempted to change things as you're reading?
I do.
Do you?
Oh, sure.
And depending what the audience looks like also, you may leave out a word or make a contraction or one thing or another.
Yeah, very interesting.
Excuse me, I hope you don't mind going off.
I grew up on lentil soup, too, by the way.
I happen to say my mother made wonderful lentil soup when I was there.
Oh, do I mention lentil soup?
Oh, my grandmother.
My grandmother made it, yeah.
It wasn't really that good.
But I was a kid.
You remember it with affection, though.
Well, I was a kid and didn't know any better.
It was very clear.

a lentil soup i bet you know you can see i thought that was more greek well dark yes dark and there was sometimes with carrots you described learning are you a product of your reading would you say have you been shaped by the books that you've read you talk about learning sex from books for instance from a family yeah very early on yeah and to expand that
The reason I ask the question is very selfish.
A chapter in my new book is I'm really fascinated by people who can really palpably
shaped by the books that they've read.
Well, Virginia Woolf never went to school, you know, and everything she became for the reading.
Shaw read at the British Library at his university, you know.
Well, I mean, I think that's quite true.
Probably the finest education, not technical, of course, but the finest liberal education would come from reading because...

The books will tell you things that you're not going to learn any other way, and tell you in terms that are marvelous, that just don't, are not so clarified in life, not so, you know, you cannot... So I would say the answer is yes.
But there's another part to the, I mean, another aspect to the question,
Which is, would you have been different?
Have they changed your character, so to speak?
I don't believe they do that.
I believe they broaden you.
They change your soul, but not your character.
That's excellent.
Because I think in your case, your writing really does reflect your experience.
More so, perhaps, even... Here, you mean, or everywhere?
Everywhere.
Well... Your books have reflected the things that have happened in your life from when it's... Well, to some extent, I mean, they're not all autobiographical by any means.
No, but they certainly are influenced by the things that you... That I've seen and done, yes.
But that's the power of fiction, of course, to create something fictional.
That you haven't seen or experienced, in a way?
You know, I...
I'm teaching writing now in this stint at Williams first semester.
I've done it a couple times before at Iowa, actually.
And you were obliged to rethink these things all the time in addressing students and addressing these problems.
I believe in whoever it was that says your job is to invent the truth.

it's not a question of making things up that phrase bothers me a bit i it's true you may be writing down things that haven't happened but they better be the truth despite that and that's what makes a great uh i think a great book or the book the kind of book i like in any case and not only me i would say that that identifies many of the works that we consider

uh you know worth reading enduring so uh they are true but uh hey i i don't want you to talk about reviews uh the reviews have been wonderful on this book but i noticed how they they generally coach and say well this is a book about the male experience have you seen these reviews somewhere like that yeah what's your response to that true
I would say that has a little bit of current fashion and PC-ism and so forth.
Yeah, because I know that the viewer is almost apologizing that he hasn't liked it because it is taking the position of a white, middle-aged guy in the late 20th century.
essentially the most popular people.
Yeah, well, all right, but male sexuality and male issues and these kinds of things.
It's like you have to apologize.
Well, they do.
They are apologetic or a little grudging or a little nervous about liking it too much for fear they'll be attacked from the radical, whatever, left or right.
I don't think that's anything to worry about.
I mean, men's affection for women, such as it is, that's not going to change, no matter what customs dictate at the moment.
I don't think the attitudes in the book are at all a question of my generation.
I think that they are absolutely valid, and...
I'm not concerned about that.
I could be completely wrong.
I was wrong about the hunters.
I could be completely wrong about this, but I don't think so.
I don't think so either, because people are leading it with great pleasure.
The writing is beautiful, and I can see why it took 10 years to write it.
Well, it shouldn't.
It represents really like two and a half years' work, but I'm slow.
Another guy could have
done it probably in a couple of years.
But you had other things to do, right?
I did.
I was trying to earn a little money and teach and I had a kid and I don't know what happens.
I've never completely given up living is the problem.
You haven't really talked about Hollywood and screenwriting and stuff like that.
You've been very critical about your own
I guess you've been quoted as saying there's only one screenplay that you really feel achieved it.
Well, came close to achieving it, I would say.
I suppose it's my nature.
I mean, when something is really good, I usually don't talk about it.
I just let it be.
If it's not quite good, I'm willing to admit that it was my fault or that it could be better.
It didn't make it.
I suppose that's what it amounts to.
Movies are, you know this, and most educated moviegoers, I would think, know this.
They depend so much on the cast and the director, apart from the writer.
The writer is only the initial, you know, the father of it, let us say, in a way.
The producer would claim to be the father.
Actually, the writer provides the, you know, the text for it.
But after that, it's in a lot of other hands that have nothing to do with the writer.
So good scripts are ruined sometimes.
No, that's fine.
Good scripts are ruined by bad luck in casting or by the wrong director and maybe other things as well.
And I would say that I had, my luck wasn't great in film writing.
I can think of a script or maybe a script and a half that would have been much better if it had, would have been good if it had the right people, but it didn't.
And that happens.
You've got to accept that.
Did you feel any kind of a proprietary way about your scripts as you do about your novels?
No, not quite, but I was quite serious about it.
I mean, I did my, I gave them whatever I had to give them.
It wasn't a question of
doing it with my left hand or with my fingers crossed and saying, well, this is nothing but a movie.
So you gave me a shot.
Yes, I did it the way you write a column.
You do the best you can.
And so, no, I didn't approach it cynically and say, well, what's the difference?
It's only a movie, and what do all those unwashed people?
No.
But it doesn't always come out.
I don't, those are the breaks.
I don't, you know, it's partly my fault, partly luck, all those things.
How many films did Faulkner have produced, I wonder?
Did William Faulkner have produced that he did and basically supported him?
Yes, well I know at least one that he wrote, something about the pharaohs, I can't remember.
But other than that, you know,
Yeah.
Well, did you enjoy that work?
Oh, yes.
I think you enjoyed it, especially at the beginning, in the early part of doing it.
It's very exciting.
It's very exciting to have everybody suddenly assuring you that you are quite an important figure and waiting eagerly.
for what you produce.
And then this, you're more than on the fringe, you're meeting a lot of people traveling, the hotels, this and that.
You said earlier in our conversation that, jokingly, but a literary writer is a writer whose books don't sell.
But Jim, but take that half seriously.
Do you think
What is your attitude on the future of serious literature, of literature, of literary novels?
Well, I think overall I would say literature has declined a bit in importance in our culture, in our world.
Will it continue to slip?
I don't know.
Is it a bad thing?
I don't really know.
I think you have to accept it, as you accept change in the seashore or something.
It happened.
Everything that has happened in the second half of the century, technologically, has made a big difference.
And some things that happened in the first half, film for instance, have made a difference.
It's wonderful.
It's like driving in a taxi cab and arguing with the cab driver about whether the baseball team, about what they should have done or not, and is it good or not.
Nobody really knows.
The novel Dead, I wouldn't say that.
Less important than it was when Thackeray was writing, or Henry James.
who was incidentally not one of the most popular writers in his generation.
Or Melville for that matter.
No, I mean, but less important than that?
Yes, probably.
Somebody pointed out Margaret Drabble, I didn't interview with her a couple of years ago.
The fact is, you think of the great Russian novelists, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Reunion, they wrote these wonderful novels at a time when the vast majority of the Russian people couldn't read.
And yet, the literature was still produced, so whether or not, you know, there's a decline in literacy or interest or whatever,
It doesn't necessarily mean that the literature will not be produced.
That's true.
And, of course, the literature is carried on by a small minority of people in any case.
In any case.
In any case.
I think so.
I mean, by academics, by avid readers, by people, book lovers.
So, I don't, it's hard to say.
There seems to be less time to read these days than there was in life.
That's a good point.
But having said all this, do you write with a certain reader in mind?
Well, I write things that I would like to read.
I write things for myself, first of all, that I enjoy reading.
And secondly, I guess I write with a couple of people in mind.
a couple of type of people in mind that I would like, that I can imagine in reading it.
That's all.
If we could, again, discuss why you decided to do a volume of Recollections, and as you say, written...
about certain things, the rest have been now written.
You know, you're basically being very selective about what you're going to write about.
In some other place, I said I was actually was writing light years.
I remember I was... I had in mind something Jean Renoir had said when he said, the only things that are important in life are the things you remember.
That's a charming aphorism, and it's like a mebius.
Is it a mebius strip?
What is that thing where you go inside and outside on the piece of paper as you follow it?
Because it's self-defining in a way.
Of course, if you don't remember it, of what importance can it be?
But at the same time, I think he meant something else.
I think he meant those things.
The only things that are important are the things that are embedded.

in your heart and in your soul since they happened or you heard them or whatever and it was those things that i was i was looking for things that had really shaped me or that i was afraid would shape me and leaving out a lot of the rest i didn't want to write a book such as everybody else had written only out of this
I would say, perhaps unwise idea of doing original things.
And so that's the way I wrote it.
I mean, I could write another book just like it and tell a lot of things.
that aren't in this, and maybe it would be just as interesting, but I don't believe I'm going to do it once is enough.
The book also only goes up to about 1975, 1980.
I mean, it stops almost 20 years ago.
So there is room
For more?
You mean volume two?
Tell your readers not to be apprehensive.
But this book, I bet it's doing very well commercially.
Do you think it is?
Well, for me, it is.
Do you think that maybe more people will get to know you through your recollections than they might have say through your novels?
Oh, unquestionably.
Yes.
that's going to do that.
